Chapter 3, part 3 on the three kinds of discernment, the section on dependent origination, after discussing the four kinds of birth,
it was previously said that hell beings, gods, and intermediate beings
are only born supernaturally. What dharmas are called intermediate beings in this context?
Why are intermediate beings not called birth?
Verse:
The five aggregates between death and birth are called intermediate existence,
Because it has not yet reached the place it should reach, therefore intermediate existence is not birth.
Discussion:

After death existence and before birth existence, in the middle there arises its own body, in order to reach the place of birth it gives rise to this body, because it is between the two existences it is called intermediate existence.
How is it that this existence has arising and perishing but is not called birth?
Also, does this bodily existence come from karma or does it exist by itself?
That which is obtained from action should be called birth, because action is the cause of birth, as the scriptures say.
That which exists by itself should have no cause, and then one would fall into the error of the non-Buddhist doctrine of causelessness.
Therefore the intermediate existence should be called birth.
Birth means the place to which one should go in the future. The name birth is established based on the meaning of arriving at that place.
Although the body of this intermediate existence arises and perishes, it has not yet arrived there, so it is not called birth.

The body refers to the five aggregates of karmic maturation in this intermediate existence. It is only called arising, not birth, because it arises temporarily in the intermediate existence between death and birth.
Or, birth means that which is to be produced. The intermediate existence is able to produce, so it is not birth.
What is it that is produced?
It refers to the five aggregates of karmic maturation that are finally manifested and clearly distinguished by karma.

Because karma is said to be the cause of birth in the scriptures, it should be called birth. This reasoning is not correct, because not all that is said to be the cause of karma is called birth. Therefore the scriptures say:
There are sentient beings who have already eliminated the fetters of rebirth but have not yet eliminated the fetters of birth. The four alternatives are explained in detail.

By this we know that there are karmas that lead to rebirth in the intermediate state but not to rebirth in the next life. The results obtained by this karma are not called rebirth. Therefore, there is no contradiction with that sutra.
Since this is led by the same karma as rebirth, how can the intermediate state be called arising but not rebirth?
Isn't it said before that the place where one arrives and goes is called rebirth, but the intermediate state is not like this?
Moreover, there is no fault in the result of one karma being many, just as one moment of karma has many moments of result, and one formless realm karma has form and formless realm results.
In the same way, how can there be a contradiction in the principle that the result led by one karma has rebirth and arising?
Other schools hold that there is no intermediate state, but this contradicts both principle and teachings.

As for contradicting principle, the previous aggregates cease in one place, and the subsequent ones arise in a different place, both of which have faults. This means that if the previous aggregates cease in one place and the subsequent ones arise in a different place, then there is no intermediate state.
Why do you not admit that the intermediate existence is born in another place without any interval after death?

If the aggregates of the prior existence perish in this place and the aggregates of the subsequent existence are born in this place without an intermediate existence, then you must admit that the aggregates of the subsequent existence are born in this place without any interval after death.
In this way, the intermediate existence is different from the place where the prior existence perished. If it is born, it is born in another place. If it is not born, it is useless to be born.
Therefore, the aggregates of the subsequent existence are born without any interval after death. The principle is well established, and therefore there is no intermediate existence.

Also, because the existence of an intermediate existence is not taught by the scriptures. That is, some scriptures teach that there are three kinds of karma, that is, karma whose results are experienced in the present life, etc. There is no scripture that teaches that there is a fourth kind of karma whose results are experienced in an intermediate existence. It cannot be said that an intermediate existence is born without karma, because then everything would be born without a cause.
Also, because all sentient beings would be endowed with supernatural powers. That is, all sentient beings would naturally possess supernatural powers and freedom without effort.
However, many expend effort and few achieve success. Therefore, an intermediate existence must be nonexistent.
Also, if you admit that there is death, there must be birth, because there is death only if there is birth.

Also, if you admit that there is death without birth, then there would be the error of too much, because even though there is no sudden birth in the various destinies, there would be sudden death. The principle of death without birth is extremely contradictory.
Also, there would be the error of both existence and nonexistence of grasping, because does the intermediate existence grasp after death or not?
If it grasps, then it would be born, because of the scriptures. A scripture says,
â€œWhen one abandons this body and grasps another body, I predict that one will be born.â€
If it does not grasp, then it should enter nirvÄá¹‡a. Since it has entered nirvÄá¹‡a, how could there be an intermediate existence?

Also, there would be the error of endlessness, because if there is an intermediate existence between death and birth, then how could there be no intermediate existence between the birth of the intermediate existence and death?
If there is, then there would be the error of endlessness.
Thus we have briefly discussed the contradictions with reason and the contradictions with the teachings.
Now we will explain further. The World-Honored One said:
Beings who are stream-enterers are reborn at most seven times.
If there were an intermediate existence, the World-Honored One should have said that they are reborn at most fourteen times.
Moreover, the uninterrupted karma would become interrupted, because a scripture says:
Having committed the five uninterrupted karmas, one is immediately reborn in hell.
If there were an intermediate existence in between, it would contradict the meaning of being uninterrupted.
Moreover, the existence of an intermediate existence is refuted in a scripture, which says:
Regeneration, you now pass beyond the flourishing stage, and approach the end of life under the king of death.
Desiring to go on the road ahead but lacking provisions, seeking to stay in the middle but having no place to rest.
If there were an intermediate existence, how could the World-Honored One say that there is no place to rest in between?
Moreover, it is not the object of the knowledge of past abodes, because a scripture says:
One who knows past abodes says, 'I died there and was reborn here.'
It does not say that after dying, one was first born in an intermediate existence.
Because it contradicts such principles and teachings, we know for sure that there is no intermediate existence to be obtained.
The previous school's assertions are briefly described in this way. Now, I say that all of them are not established by evidence.

First, as for their statement that the previous aggregates cease and the subsequent ones arise differently, both incurring faults, this objection is unreasonable, because it is accepted that the intermediate existence arises adjacent to the place of death.

That is to say, it is accepted that the intermediate existence arises adjacent to the place of death, neither separated nor immediately adjacent. In this way, it arises adjacent to the subsequent [rebirths] up to the point of rebirth, and thus there is no previous fault. This will be further revealed when explaining our own school.
Moreover, their statement that the intermediate existence is not mentioned in the scriptures is also unreasonable, because it is mentioned in some places.
That is to say, a scripture says:
By this defiled body I have created evil karma, I wish that all of it be transformed into present retribution, not following, not being born, not to be experienced in the future.
Isn't it clear that the intermediate existence is indicated by the word following?
That is to say, the ripening of skillful and unskillful karma that is experienced in the present life, in the next life, or in subsequent lives is generally called following.

The name of the middle one is that of the retribution of skillful means, because there is evil karma that conforms to the retribution of the intermediate state. Therefore, it is said that one should not follow the words of the vow.
Or, karma that can summon the future destiny is able to produce the retribution of the intermediate state.
The two existences of the intermediate state and birth are drawn by one karma, as has been explained previously. Therefore, the karma of the intermediate state cannot be said to be nonexistent.
However, the World-Honored Buddha briefly explains three kinds of definite karmas, and the karma that summons the intermediate state is included in them. Therefore, he does not explain it separately.
Moreover, it is said that all sentient beings should be endowed with spiritual powers. This is also not contrary to reason, because this state exists.
If in the state of the intermediate state, all sentient beings are endowed with the spiritual powers accomplished by karma, what fault is there in this?
This state does not exist, but it is not the case for the rest. Do not take the example of a jackal or other ordinary beings at one time and take it as always being so.

Or you should slander the existence of the intermediate state, because you allow that all sentient beings possess supernatural powers, that is, all sentient beings, having died in this place, can go to a place extremely far away, beyond innumerable yojanas, and are born there without any obstruction at all. What other great supernatural power is there besides this?
Also, the objection that if you allow that there is death and birth, then there must be existence as birth, is also unreasonable, because we allow that birth is a different kind of existence.

The proponents of the theory of the intermediate state establish the name existence as birth for a particular kind of birth, not for existence as birth itself. It is like going to the realm of humans. In the interval before arriving, there is a particular kind of birth, which is the means of birth. One is not yet called a human, but one has already obtained the name human. One has not yet reached the place where one should be born, because one is attracted by a single action.
For this reason, there is no sudden death in the various destinies, because it is allowed that the intermediate state is the means of birth.
For this reason, this also answers the question of whether there is a cause for grasping, because grasping is named the intermediate state.

The word â€œbodyâ€ in the above passage does not refer only to form, because we also see the word â€œbodyâ€ used in reference to that which is not form. The three realms of existence are called â€œbirthâ€ in the sense of the origination of birth, and the Buddha said that one â€œabandons this body and takes on another body.â€ What is wrong with this being called birth?

If you say that the word â€œbodyâ€ in the above passage refers only to form, and that one who abandons this body and takes on an immaterial body is not born, then why did the Buddha not say that one is not born?

Even if we grant that the word â€œbodyâ€ refers to form, there is no error. When the Buddha said that one abandons this body and takes on another body, he was only saying that one is born, not that one is born in a place of existence.
It is not only in the place of existence that one is born that one can be said to be born, because the word â€œbirthâ€ is used to deny death, just as the word â€œrainâ€ is used to deny drought.
Nor is there an infinite regress, because we admit that the next birth is produced immediately after death, and there is no error in this.
If the intermediate existence between death and birth were separated by a place of existence, then there would be an infinite regress as you have said.
But the intermediate existence between death and birth is produced immediately after death. Since there is no interval, what need is there to establish a place of existence?
Therefore, the fault of infinite regress does not apply to our school.
Moreover, since our school establishes the existence of an intermediate state, it would cause the intermediate state to have another intermediate state;
in the same way, your school only establishes the existence of birth, and birth would also have another birth.
The faults of both sides are the same, so it should not be a problem.
In this way, we refute the principle of blocking the intermediate state. Next, we will explain and clarify the teaching of blocking the intermediate state.
The sÅ«tra says that the stream-enterer has at most seven existences. This does not contradict the existence of the intermediate state, because it speaks of a single period of birth as one existence.

That is to say, the intermediate state and so forth are collectively called a single period of birth, because they are of the same form and so forth, drawn by a single karma. In this way, the four existences are collectively established as one existence, so there is no fault of the stream-enterer having at most fourteen existences.
The existence of a single period of birth is divided into four existences according to the differences in causes and conditions and states.
Or, the statement of seven existences is made according to the existence of birth in the human realm, so there is also no contradiction.
In your system, you also admit that those who have entered the stream may experience seven existences in the heavens. They should be limited to fourteen.

Or, their intention may be that the words â€œat most seven existencesâ€ do not separately indicate seven existences in the heavens and seven existences in the human realm, but rather indicate that the total number of existences in the heavens and the human realm is only seven.

If this is so, then you should say that sentient beings who have entered the stream run through birth and death in the heavens and the human realm for seven existences. The sÅ«tra should not say that sentient beings who have entered the stream run through birth and death in the heavens and the human realm for seven existences each. Therefore, we know that the sÅ«traâ€™s statement that they experience â€œat most seven existencesâ€ indicates that there are seven existences in the heavens and seven existences in the human realm separately.
You should not insist on this, because it contradicts other sÅ«tras. The sÅ«tra says:
â€œA person who has complete insight has no place and no possibility of experiencing an eighth existence.â€
There is no fault of contradicting the sÅ«tras, because it continues from the previous sÅ«tra.
That is, the sÅ«tra previously said that those who have entered the stream experience seven existences in the heavens and the human realm each, and definitely not an eighth.

Next, it is impossible for a person who has complete insight to experience an eighth existence. Therefore, the sutra passage that says that one experiences a maximum of seven existences does not contradict the tenets of our school.
Also, the statement that the uninterrupted karma would become an interrupted karma is also unreasonable, because it is a prohibition against a different realm.

That is to say, if one commits an uninterrupted karma, it is definitely not interrupted by a different realm, and one will certainly be born in hell. I see the meaning of this sutra as being like this.

Or, perhaps the intermediate existence is also included in hell, and therefore there is no error of an uninterrupted karma becoming an interrupted karma, because one is born in the intermediate existence of hell.

If one maintains that there is a little something in the middle that separates the two, and that it is not uninterrupted, then the uninterrupted karma would definitely be nonexistent, because it is definitely not the case that one commits an uninterrupted karma and then in the next moment is born in hell.
If one says that there is no error, because a sutra says that one is born in hell immediately after the body perishes, this is also unreasonable, because the body perishes in a moment.
If you say that the word â€œperishesâ€ refers to the end of a life, we also say that the intermediate existence is born, but it is born in the intermediate existence.

The scripture says that when the body perishes, one is born in hell, but it does not say that one is born in the intermediate existence of hell. Therefore, the word â€œimmediatelyâ€ excludes other destinies.
If you do not admit this, then there would be no immediate retribution.
Therefore, the scripture that speaks of actions with immediate retribution has no power to deny the existence of the intermediate existence.

The scripture says that when the body perishes, one is born in hell, but it does not say that one is born in the intermediate existence of hell. How does this prove that there is no intermediate existence?
There are people who are like children in their playfulness and set forth objections.

If the word â€œimmediatelyâ€ excludes other destinies, then there is no intermediate existence, and the principle is completely established, because you yourself hold that the intermediate existence is different from the destinies, and you admit that the word â€œimmediatelyâ€ excludes other destinies.
Their words are not good, because they admit a different meaning.

The meaning of the statement that it is to prevent rebirth in other destinies is that the two destinies are separate, just as two villages are called different villages, and that which is not included in destinies is called different destinies.
How can such childish playwords be used to investigate and prove the true meaning?
Therefore, it is certain that there is an intermediate state, and such a sutra is not easily found.
Moreover, this intermediate state definitely exists, because it is only said to be without interruption.
If there were no intermediate state, then when the body of a sentient being with afflictions perishes, they would all immediately be reborn.
If the sutra only spoke of this, it would be useless.

I explain this sutra as saying that the word without interruption is to prevent other destinies from being separated by an intermediate state, and to prevent the intermediate state from being delayed due to the lack of conditions. Therefore, this sutra has a profound meaning. Apart from this, other karmas do not have this definite prevention, so they are not said to be immediate karmas.
If you explain this sutra as preventing the intermediate state, then all karmas would become immediate.
Therefore you should believe that the meaning of the sutra is established, or else you deny the sutra and establish a meaning that is not the meaning of the sutra.
Moreover, in this sutra, the word immediately is seen, and this word is used to block the intermediate state;
others allow an interval, and the intermediate state should be established.

Moreover, in another sutra, it is said that there is parinirvana in the intermediate state, so the meaning of this sutra should be carefully considered. If one only grasps the text, there is the fault of going too far.
That is to say, a sutra says:
There is a type of sentient being who, having committed and increased the five heinous karmas, will definitely be reborn in the hells immediately without fail.
If one only grasps the text, one should definitely commit all five in order to be reborn in hell, and not by lacking one or by other karmic causes, which would be going too far.
Moreover, the word immediately being reborn in the hells should mean being reborn immediately, not waiting for the body to perish.
This has already explained the sutra that blocks the intermediate state.
That is to say, the Buddha instructed:
You will die from here and definitely quickly fall, without being reborn in a different realm. There is also no temporary stopping in the intermediate state.
If it were not so, then all sentient beings would be born immediately after death, and not just this one.
Therefore, by this evidence, the existence of an intermediate state is established.

Also, the statement that it is not the object of the knowledge of past lives is also unreasonable, because it is a brief indication of the destinies.ğŸ”½The knowledge of past lives does not take the intermediate state as its object, but it is a brief indication of the destinies.
Therefore, it says:
I died from there and was reborn here.
If it were otherwise, it should also say:
I received this birth as a kalala, etc.
Since it does not say that, this should also be non-existent;
since this is not non-existent, the intermediate state should be so.
Or, the statement dying from there and being reborn here already includes the intermediate state, because this birth includes it.
Thus, the other schools' refutations of the intermediate state are all without superior power to refute the intermediate state.
The masters of the Abhidharma-samuccaya say:
The intermediate state definitely exists, because of reason and teaching.
What are the reason and teaching?
The verse says:
Just as the continuity of grains, without interruption in place, continues to arise,
The analogy of the reflection is not established as real, because it is not equal.
Two things do not exist simultaneously in one place, and it does not arise from the continuity of two things,
Because it is said that there is a gandharva, and because of the five and seven sutras.
The treatise says:
First, by correct reasoning, the intermediate existence is not non-existent.
If the intermediate existence were non-existent, then it would definitely not exist to die in one place and continue in another place.

One has never seen in the world a dharma that continues to transform, that can continue to arise without interruption in place. Since it is accepted that sentient beings die in one place and are born in another place, one must definitely accept that the intermediate existence that connects them in the middle is not non-existent.

For example, it is like the continuity of grains in the world. It is seen that grains, etc., continue to be born in another place, and there is definitely no interruption in the middle place. Therefore, the continuity of sentient beings is also like this. The continuity of arising in a moment definitely has no interruption in place. Therefore, the existence of the intermediate existence is established as real.

Donâ€™t we see in the world that even though a place is interrupted, a subsequent arising can occur? For example, a reflection arises in a mirror from the original object. The principle of the two existences of death and rebirth should be the same.
Here the ÅšÄstra master explains this as follows: The existence of images is not established by principle.
Also, because they are not the same, the analogy is not established.
The arising of a separate form is called an image. Its substance is truly existent, but this is not established by principle.
Even if it is established, it is not the same, so it is not an analogy.
What is the reason that the substance of an image is not truly existent?
Because two things do not exist in the same place.
They say that in one place, the form of the mirror and the image are both seen present. Two forms should not exist in the same place, because they rely on different elements.

Also, in shallow water, the forms on both banks are the same in place and appear simultaneously. Those on both banks see them clearly, but never see two forms in the same place. It should not be said that these two forms arise together.

Also, shadows and light are never in the same place. Yet one has seen a mirror hung in a shadow, and the image of light clearly appears on the surface of the mirror. One should not say that two things are produced together in this case.
Or, if it is said that two things are not produced together in one place, the image of the moon in a mirror is said to be two things. One sees it as near or far, just as one sees well water.
If two things are produced together, how can one see them separately?
Therefore, one should know that images do not really exist in principle.
However, the power of the combination of various causes and conditions makes one see in this way. The various natures and functions of dharmas are difficult to imagine.
Now, I say that those causes cannot eliminate images, so they cannot understand the refutation of the existence of the intermediate state.
Moreover, what they say, that two things do not exist in one place, is unreasonable, because the wall and light can both be grasped in the same place.

Although the colors of the wall and light are different and have different elements as their basis, they can both be grasped in the same place at the same time. One cannot deny that the light is on the wall.
Therefore, we know that both the mirror and the image exist. Therefore, the reason given by the opponent is not a valid refutation of the existence of images.

If you say that the light is supported by the primary elements of the sunâ€™s disk, and therefore there is no error, this is also unreasonable, because heat and touch are like light and can be grasped nearby.
Also, the color of sunlight should have no support, because it is admitted that the supported can exist apart from the support.

In the same way, although the primary elements that support the two colors of the mirror and the image are different, they can be in the same place. Therefore, the reason given by the opponent, namely, that the two colors are in different places because they are supported by different primary elements, is useless.
Also, the primary elements must be in the same place, because they have no different primary elements that support them.

If you say that this error does not occur because the primary elements are resistant, then you cannot prove that the mirror and the image are in different places because they are supported by different primary elements, because the primary elements that produce and the primary elements that are produced are resistant and the same.
The correct principle is that you should only say that the two colors of the mirror and the image are both resistant and therefore cannot be in the same place.
Since they cannot be in the same place, how can you say that the color of the mirror and the image are both seen in the same place?

If you say that because the places are different they cannot be grasped, this is also unreasonable, because it has already been explained that the colors of the wall and light can be grasped in the same place.
However, because they are resistant, in reality their places are not the same.
Although their places are not the same, they can be grasped as the same, just as the light and the wall. The reflection is also like this.

Now I will explain for you how they can be grasped as the same. Because the color of the reflection is extremely clear and subtle, it cannot obstruct the other colors. Because the mirror and the reflection are extremely close to each other, one gives rise to the conceit that they are grasped in the same place, just as the extremely clear and subtle colors of mica, etc., when separated from the other colors, if they are extremely close to each other, one gives rise to the conceit that they are grasped in the same place.
Or, as explained above, although the light and the wall are different, they can be grasped in the same place at the same time. This should be so according to that principle.
Moreover, when the colors of the two banks appear in a single body of water, they are seen simultaneously and separately, because the conditions for perception are different, one sees in this way.

That is, in one body of water, one reflection does not arise, but the clear and wondrous natures are not obstructed from each other. If the conditions for seeing come together, then one can see them. If the conditions for seeing are lacking, then one cannot see them.

Or, in one place, two conditions for seeing may come together, and they observe the same form and appearance, not a different one. That is, in one mirror, one sees one reflection, and the other also sees it there.
If in the mirror, etc., no separate reflection arises the same as in other places, what definite cause is there that only in the mirror, etc., do they see the form and appearance together?
Or, with regard to one form, two sentient beings may separately abide and observe it together, one seeing it and one not seeing it.

Just as on a clean board, if one applies bone ash and draws a picture, after a long time, even if one draws a new picture on the ground or wall, facing the light or with the back to the light, there is seeing and not seeing.ğŸ”½It is not that with regard to one form, two can observe it together. One should not use this to give an analogy to the rest, all of which are seen together.
One should not use the fact that with regard to one form, it cannot be observed together, to give an analogy to the rest, all of which are not seen together.
Therefore, their explanation is not reasonable.

As for the statement that light and shadow are mutually exclusive in the same place, and the reflection of the moon is seen in a different place than the mirror surface, this will be refuted later in the argumentation of the Venerable RÄma, and this criticism will be addressed at the same time.
He states:
The various images in mirrors and so forth do not really exist as form, because it is unreasonable that they be either a part or a universal.

That is to say, it is unreasonable that the form of the image be produced either by taking the moon as its cause and being produced in dependence on a part of the water, or by being produced in dependence on the water as a universal.
It is unreasonable that it be produced in dependence on a part of the water, because there is no fixed cause for this, and because it is omnipresent and evolves.
It is also unreasonable that it be produced in dependence on the water as a universal, because it is seen to have a limited extent. Since both are unreasonable, it is not form.

Moreover, because shadow and light are mutually exclusive, that is to say, when two mirrors are placed in the light and shadow, the images of light and shadow appear alternately on the mirror surfaces.
We actually see light and shadow mutually obstructing each other. If the two images were real derivative form, they should not both be perceptible in the same place.
Since they are both actually perceptible, they are not real derivative form.
Also, there is a difference in the mode of perception, because many are perceived.

When the image of Devadatta appears in water, etc., because of a difference in the mode of perception, various colors are perceived, such as blue, yellow, red, and white. When one is perceived, the others are not. It is not possible for different colors to occupy the same place.
Even if it is admitted that they occupy the same place, why are they not all perceived at once?
Therefore we know that there is no separate derivative form in this case.
Also, there is no difference in the amount of the image, because movement is perceived.
When Devadatta faces a mirror, the image that appears is no different in amount from him, but the function of going and coming is perceived to be different.
This is not possible for a single piece of derivative form.
But since this is perceived, the image is not derivative form.
Also, because the support of the image is perceived to be different.
When the moonâ€™s image appears supported by water, etc., the image is perceived to be in a different place from its support.
If the reflected image arises on the surface of the water, then one should not see it as distant or near;
but since it is seen as distant or near, it is not a derivative form.
If that is so, then what is seen in it?

Because the substance is the condition for the arising of visual consciousness, just as visual consciousness can arise conditioned by the eye and form, so too can visual consciousness arise conditioned by the eye and a mirror, etc., and the substance facing the mirror, etc. One actually sees the substance, but it is said that one sees a separate image.
Now, we say that those reasons also cannot refute the image.

Moreover, what they say, that part and whole are both unreasonable, therefore derivative form is not so, because the rest is the same.ğŸ”½That is to say, if one admits that visual consciousness arises conditioned by the eye and a mirror, etc., facing the substance in the mirror, etc., then these two kinds of objections are the same, because part and whole are both unreasonable.
That is to say, seeing the substance again takes the mirror, etc. as a condition, either part or whole, both are unreasonable.
It is not that a part of the mirror, etc., is the condition, because there is no fixed cause, and because it is able to appear before all other places as the condition for seeing.
It is also not that the mirror, etc., are able to be the condition everywhere, because what is seen is clear and limited.
Since both are unreasonable, it is a mistaken opinion.

We do not admit that the moon, etc., are the cause, and that a part of water, etc., is the support that produces the reflection. It is only that the object and the support are opposite without separation. The law of nature is that the reflection of the object is produced in the support.
How can it be possible that the reflection is produced only in a part of the support?
How do you know that the reflection is produced everywhere in the support?
It is seen that many people line up beside a long canal, and each sees the reflection of the moon opposite their own face.
If that is so, why is it that one does not see many?

In this way, the conditions for seeing are not combined. Although the reflection of the moon is produced everywhere, it is only in the present that the conditions for seeing are combined. Therefore, it can be seen in one part but not in another. The side is lacking in the conditions of light, because it is obstructed by darkness.
Other masters explain it in this way:
The reflected image is light and subtle, and when it is close it is easy to see, but when it is far it is difficult to see.
Or, if it gradually increases, one sees many. Therefore, in this case, one should not raise objections.
If it is many, then there is not one that can see many, so it cannot be objected.
If blue, yellow, etc. can be seen together, this should also be the same as many reflected particles, because they can be seen together.
However, the reason why the reflected moon has a limited size is because its original substance has a limited size. The reflected image must follow the original substance on which it is based.
Or, if the original substance has no limited size as a condition, a limitless reflected image arises in the water, just like the blue sky is reflected in the water.
Therefore, because the original substance has a limited size, although the reflected image of the moon arises everywhere, its limited size is seen without error.
Or, if it is said that a mirror, etc. as a condition still reflects the original substance in front of it, although it may be partially or completely a condition, it is not reasonable in either case.
However, it is definitely admitted that the mirror, etc., are conditions for seeing the substance.
The arising of images is also like this. Why bother to argue?

Moreover, what they say, namely, that because light and shadow are mutually contradictory, they should not occupy the same place, and therefore it is known that images do not exist, is also unreasonable, because it is not admitted.
That is to say, when two mirrors are hung in light and shadow, the two images that appear are not real light and shadow, because their form cannot be apprehended like that of form.
If that is so, what is it that is clearly seen?

That is to say, the light and shadow of the two substances, such as the wall, etc., give rise to images of light in the two mirror surfaces without contradiction. They are not the colors of light and shadow.
Just as the image of a sentient being is not a real sentient being, therefore the images of light are not real light and shadow. Although they appear in the same place, they are not contradictory.
Moreover, what they hold to be the school, namely, that shadows are not real things, since they have no real substance, what is it that is contradictory?

It cannot be said that there is a contradiction in something that does not exist. Therefore, in terms of your assertion, there is also no meaning of contradiction. Then the reason you state is not accepted by either party. What you say about light and shadow contradicting each other,
if something exists, it should not be apprehended in the same place. What is the meaning of these words?
If light and shadow really exist, they should contradict each other and should not occupy the same place.
Since they do not occupy the same place, they should not be apprehensible;
since they are both apprehensible, therefore the reflection is truly non-existent. The meaning of what I said previously is like this.
Is it only that what is truly non-existent is definitely not apprehensible?
Is there anything that is truly non-existent but also apprehensible, or is there anything that is truly existent but not apprehensible?
If so, what is the use of saying that if they do not occupy the same place, they should not be apprehensible?
Even though they do not occupy the same place, they should still be apprehensible, because what you assert as non-existent can also be apprehended.
It cannot be said that not all non-existents are apprehensible, because there is no different reason.
Because all are without characteristics and without distinctions, they cannot be said to be graspable or ungraspable.

Moreover, what they say, that the many are grasped due to the distinction of states, and therefore images are not real, this statement is also not contradictory regarding images. Only in the existent, due to the distinction of states, many colors can be grasped, but not in the non-existent.

It is necessary that regarding the actually seen object, due to the distinction of the faculties, clarity, distance, direction, etc., there can be right and wrong, with the understanding of color being different.
Just as observing the actually existent color illuminated by the sunlight, the color of a spider's web, the tail of a peacock, the direction of a wheel, etc., the views have differences.
It is also like observing and seeing a whirling fire wheel, etc. Therefore, it is definitely known that there are real images, with the many being grasped due to the distinction of states.
Therefore, their refuting reason, on the contrary, proves the existence of images.
Or, just as the flame of a lamp is mixed with many colors, due to the obstruction of the location where it resides, it does not reside everywhere, with the view being completely exhausted.
Also, it is like observing an arrow as either straight or bent. Although it grasps many, there is no fault.

Although there is no difference in color in one place, when it is grasped, it is called the same place. This principle has already been fully discussed before, so their investigation does not harm the reflection.
Also, their statement that the reflection is not real because its size is undifferentiated but its movement is seen is also unreasonable, because it has already been explained.

That is to say, although the real reflected color arises separately, the reflection must follow the original substance that it depends on. Therefore, although the size is the same, according to what is appropriate, on the basis of what it depends on, three kinds of reflected images arise, namely, the manifest, the shaped, and the moving, just like the original substance.
Because the reflection follows what it depends on and the original substance, although there is no movement, it appears as if it goes and comes, and the other two uses of movement can be obtained.

Such moving images are due to the movement of the substance in another place, or to the movement of the support, or to the movement of the observer himself, that is, the image moves. In this way, the images do not exceed the dimensions of their supports, and one sees them moving back and forth and in other ways.
What contradiction is there in this with the created form?

It is said that because one sees it, it is not created form. It cannot be that it is not created form because it is different from other created forms, just as blue and yellow, etc., are different from each other but are created form.
Or, because the characteristic of solidity is different from heat, etc., it should not be a great element. The same is the case with the others.
Just as the great elements and the created form, although different from each other, are the same in having the nature of form, therefore there is no ability to block the nature of created form.

Also, what they say, that the image and the support are seen as separate and therefore it is not created form, is also unreasonable, because the image of the moon in the sky and the image in the water are both produced in dependence on the water, etc.
That is, the color of the space element and the moon disc are arranged in sequence, with a difference of near and far. This is the cause of the difference in the place of the seen image.
The space element is existent and is included in the form realm. This has already been established, so it can each give rise to an image on water and so forth.
Because the generated image is the same as the substance, the seen and the support seem to be different places.
Or, because of seeing such a combination, it causes the seen to be far or near, even though it is not far or near.
Just as when observing a painting or embroidery, one sees high and low even though there is no high or low.
Because the moon is far, the seen image is also like this.
Just as the full moon disc is seen without a lack in the image.
By this principle, those causes are refuted.
Therefore, those causes cannot eliminate the image.
However, according to their own attachment, they speak to please the minds of the foolish, saying:
The substance is the condition that gives rise to the eye consciousness and so forth.
This interpretation is refuted by the reasonings that we have already presented.
It is unreasonable to say that the mirror and so on is either partially or wholly the condition for the arising of the reflection.
The assertion that the reflection is only a false appearance is also unreasonable, because there is no substance in the mirror and so on.
If the substance is not in the mirror, how can it be perceived in another place?
This analogy is unreasonable, because it is not the same as the original substance.
No one has ever seen a form that exists in another place and is not in contact with the eye faculty, and yet is the condition for the arising of visual consciousness.
If the visual consciousness does not arise because the condition is lacking, then you should not use this as an analogy.
How can you say that the substance exists in one place and yet is perceived in another?
The assertion that the reflection is only a false appearance is also unreasonable, because the reason you have given is not established.
Only the substance of the eye and the mirror, etc., are the conditions for the arising of visual consciousness, because it is not generally accepted that the reflection is the substance of the eye.
Only the eye and form are the conditions for the arising of visual consciousness, because this is generally accepted.
Since the image is clearly present, we know that the consciousness apprehends the image and not the substance.
Also, this must be the case, because the form of the image differs in size and color from the substance.
That is, in a mirror, etc., the image of a mountain, rock, pool, wall, tree, forest, etc., is smaller than the substance.
Also, when one sees a long face in an upright sword, etc., and a wide face in a horizontal sword, etc., the image differs in size from the substance.
Also, when one sees a face in oil, etc., the color of the face in the image differs from the substance.
If the seen image were the substance, the form and color of the image would not differ from the substance.
All things whose form and color differ from the substance are not the substance, because this is universally recognized.

We do not know what the substance of the venerable one is that is apart from form and revealing, and yet he holds that the image seen is the same as the substance, even though the revealing and form are different.

If you say that the substance is neither the same as nor different from the revealing and form, and yet it can be apprehended, then it is the same as the illusory woman of the asuras, who is skillfully created by magic to deceive fools.
If you say that it is transformed by the power of conditions, and although it is the same as that, it appears to be different, this is also not so, because it contradicts itself.
Because the principle is not established, it is not a good explanation.
If it is the same as that, it should not appear different;
since it appears to be different, it should not be the same as that.
The same as that and appearing different contradict each other. Moreover, saying that it is the same as that while appearing to be different is not established, because of the fault of going too far.

That is, the state of old age, etc., should also be grasped as being the same as the kalala, etc., of an earlier time, because they appear to be different due to transformation by the power of conditions.
Why not simply believe that the power of the combination of conditions produces a separate image, and that when one relies on conditions one still sees the original substance?
Therefore, the statement that the original substance serves as a condition to produce eye consciousness, etc., is extremely weak in reasoning and cannot be proven.
The author of the treatise says here, Therefore, we know that images do not really exist in principle, but the power of the combination of various conditions causes one to see them in this way.
Why don't they say that the power of the combination of conditions such as the substance, mirror, etc. separately produces images, and that is why one sees them in this way?
Because it is said that the power of the nature of dharmas is difficult to conceive. Moreover, the name combination is not the name of a real dharma. How can one grasp that it has power?
Moreover, grasping that many conditions combine to form one power, how can one say that dharmas have different powers?

Therefore, as a result of the differences in their capacities, the eye and form, etc., as conditions, separately attract the differences in the capacities of the visual consciousness and cause it to arise.

In the same way, as a result of the differences in their capacities, the substance and the mirror, etc., as conditions, separately attract the differences in the capacities of the reflected image and cause it to arise.
As a result of this proof, reflected images really exist, or else you must deny the existence of all dharmas.
We have heard that there are people who deny the existence of all dharmas, and now we see that the Venerable is one of them.
If this is so, there is no need to discuss this matter with you.
Moreover, if this is so, why canâ€™t someone who denies the existence of the middle way also make the following statement:

The power of the combination of causes and conditions is difficult to fathom. Even though the place of rebirth is far removed from the place of death, the power of karma can cause rebirth to occur. The nature and power of karma is difficult to fathom.
Therefore, you must think carefully about this. If a reflected image does not arise in a mirror, etc., how is it that it is clearly seen as a real thing?
Therefore the Abhidharma masters all say:

In mirrors and so forth there is a separate color of images, with a nature of a combination of the four great elements, because a separate image arises and appears. It is like this image, which is supported by the original substance.

That is to say, in mirrors and so forth, the image of the original substance appears in the mirror and so forth as a support and condition. There is a following of the original substance as a support, with the image clearly visible. The original substance that is the object of the image is truly established.

This image serves as a condition, and in a separate mirror and so forth there is also a following of the original substance as a support, with the image clearly visible. Therefore it is known that the previous image is established as truly existing because it arises as a condition for the image.
Therefore it should be known that the various images truly exist. If this were not so, what would be the condition for the other images?

If it is said that the original substance that is the object of the previous image is the condition for this, that is also unreasonable, because the previous substance does not face the subsequent support and because the subsequent image does not arise following the previous substance.
The subsequent consciousness has as its support only the image of the prior consciousness and not the prior object. How can it be said that the prior object is a condition?

We have never seen an object such as a face that is behind a mirror, etc., act as a condition to produce an image in the mirror, etc. Consequently, the subsequent image does not follow the prior object but only the prior image, and this is a matter of established fact.
Therefore, the statement that the subsequent image in a mirror, etc., is only conditioned by the prior object and not by the prior image is the mere opinion of the speaker.
How do we know that the substance of the image really exists?
Because the image does not violate the characteristics of real existence.
If it does not violate the objects of consciousness such as vision, it must be a real existent, as will be established later.
Since the image can be seen, we know that it really exists.
Also, the image is sometimes obtained and sometimes not. If it were nonexistent, it would be impossible to obtain it at any time.

Or, if you say that sometimes it is perceived and sometimes it is not perceived because of the union or nonunion of the conditions on which it depends, then you should understand that the existence of other conditioned dharmas is established by the union of conditions.

Also, because it is the object of nondiscriminating consciousness, that is, because the objects of the five consciousnesses are really existent, it is well known. But since images are perceived by visual consciousness, therefore they really exist.
Also, because images can obstruct the arising of other colors, that is, because images can obstruct the arising of other images and colors in their own place, they really exist.
If a dharma is endowed with the above characteristics, you should understand that it really exists.
Since images are like this, therefore they really exist.

Isnâ€™t it true that the previous text says that two images arise in the same place and at the same time in the same limited body of water? How can you say that images obstruct the arising of other images?

Isnâ€™t it true that the previous text says that although the places of walls, light, etc., are different, they are said to be the same place because of a false conceit, and that you should not criticize this?

Also, because the image is grasped in a different place in the mirror, that is, in a single mirror in a single place, two images cannot be obtained simultaneously. Just as the conditions are different, so too is the grasping of the images.
If you say that the nature of form is not established, this is also not so, because the principle is well established.
Moreover, how do you know that the substance of the image definitely exists?
Because it is similar to other existent dharmas that arise.

Just as consciousness, sprouts, and other dharmas that arise from conditions have a substance that is well established, so too is this. It is commonly seen in the world that [images] arise from various conditions. Therefore, one should know that the substance of the image definitely exists.
Just as other existent dharmas that are definitely established arise from separate conditions and have different characteristics,
so too are images. They arise from separate conditions and have different characteristics. Therefore, they should definitely exist.
For this reason, what you said, namely, that because it is similar to other existent dharmas that arise, the principle is well established,
is not the case, because arising does not have its own cause, as has never been seen.
The reason that â€œthe reflection does not existâ€ is also unreasonable, because we admit that the reflection has its own cause.
We admit that the reflection has a cause of the same species, just as consciousness arises from a different kind of condition.

We do not admit that the reflection is born from a mirror, etc., because we admit that the reflection is born in dependence on its own cause, and mirrors, water, and light are merely conditions that grasp it.

Just as the dust that is grasped in the light must be pierced by the light in order to cast a shadow, but the light and the shadow are not the cause of the dust, and, on the other hand, the dust does not exist without a cause.
Or we cannot say that what is born from a different kind of condition does not exist, because both the same and different colors are seen to exist.
How is it that fire and water are seen to be born from the sun, moon, and jewels? This is also so.
If you say that fire and water are born from their own seeds, because the two kinds of elements exist in the two jewels, then fire and water should be born from both jewels.
Or the two jewels should be able to produce wind and earth, because the two elements exist, just as they produce fire and water.

If it is said that the two jewels increase the two realms, and therefore are the conditions for the production of fire and water of their own kind, this is also unreasonable, because the two jewels should have heat and moisture, because they are actually perceived.ğŸ”½If it is said that the two jewels must be grasped by the light of the sun and moon, and then the two realms increase, and only then can they be the conditions for the production of fire and water, then it should be that both produce fire and water, because they are both grasped by the light.

If the two jewels have no increase or decrease in the realms, then what is the reason that the flame of heat is a condition that assists the sun jewel in causing the production of fire, and is not a condition that assists the sun jewel in causing the production of water?
It should be questioned in the same way regarding the moon jewel.
The principles of dependent origination are truly difficult to understand, because the combination of lime and water only produces fire.

It is seen in the world that when a stone is burned to lime, it can produce fire when it encounters water, but not water. This can only be said to be the difficulty of understanding dependent origination. Apart from this, what is a faultless answer?
Moreover, the arising of various colors such as rainbows is from causes, and the principle is extremely difficult to know.
Moreover, in a single color aggregate such as diamond, various powerful functions are manifested.
Moreover, in the affairs of healing humans, animals, and trees, many marvelous uses are manifested.
Moreover, when various kinds of things encounter conditions such as the hot sun, moon, and spells, they give rise to changes. Although they do not combine, they appear as causes.
Therefore, the principle of dependent origination is truly difficult to perceive.
If one understands this correct principle of dependent origination, one should not say that arising has no self-cause, because it has never been seen before and images definitely do not exist.
Those who say that images may not be nonexistent but are not derivative form, this statement is crude and shallow, so there is no need to respond to it.

If they are not derivative form, they should not be the objects of the eyes. It should only be said that images are not only derivative form. Therefore, it is logically established that images truly exist.

If the image were not produced in accordance with the principle of the object, then the example of the production of form through the interruption of space would not be established, because it is admitted that the substance of the image is connected with the support and is produced without interruption in the middle.

This means that the great elements of the moon, face, etc., are always naturally able to produce clear and wonderful great elements, which are produced without interruption and reach everywhere to the support that is present. In the place where the support is, the image color is produced in accordance with the original.
If the support is clear and pure, the image is manifest and easy to know.
If the support is coarse and impure, the image is hidden and difficult to understand.
Although there is also image color in the middle between the two, because it is clear and wonderful, it is only manifest in the support.
Just as sunlight, although it is produced everywhere, is only manifest and visible when it reaches the support of a wall, etc.
How do we know that the image is produced in connection with the substance?
Because if there is an obstruction in the middle, the image is not produced.

If the reflection were produced in the water without a continuum, then a reflection would also be produced even when there is an obstruction, just as in your theory of no intermediate state, the aggregates cease in one place and the aggregates are born in another place.

Moreover, the form of the reflection bends, stretches, bows, looks up, and moves back and forth, etc., in accordance with the substance of the original object. Therefore, it is proven that the reflection is born connected to the substance of the original object.

It cannot be cited as an analogy to refute the existence of an intermediate state. The analogy is not established because the reflection does not exist, but only because it is not the same, since it is destroyed in accordance with the original object.

It is seen that all reflections are destroyed in accordance with the original object. If birth also followed death and was destroyed, then there would be the error that the continuum of sentient beings would be severed.

Moreover, the birth of a reflection resembles the original object. The reflection of the moon, etc., definitely resembles the original object. From the death of an ox, etc., only an ox, etc., should be born.
Since this is not admitted, the analogy is not the same.

Also, many images arise from one substance. When images arise in dependence on substances, many images can arise from one substance in dependence on many mirrors, etc. But many continua of aggregates do not arise from one continuum of aggregates at death. Therefore images are not an analogy for this.
Also, substance and image are not in a continuum. Substance and image are not in a single continuum, because the image exists at the same time as the substance.
All that is in a continuum necessarily does not arise simultaneously. Because image and substance arise simultaneously, they are not in a continuum.

The continuum of sentient beings is without interruption. Death in this place and birth in another place should only be illustrated by the example of grain. Because the image is not equal, the analogy is not established.
Also, because an image arises from two causes. That is, images arise from two conditions:
first, the substance, and second, the mirror, etc. This is seen in the world.
Birth and death are not like this.
Why is this?
The existence at birth is like the image, and the existence at death is like the substance. What other dharma is there that is the support of the image?
Therefore the cited analogy is not the same as the dharma.
If semen and blood,
like the support of the image, the principle is also not so, because they are not sentient beings.
Moreover, in emptiness, etc.,
suddenly born by transformation, what is grasped in the middle as the place of support for the image?
If it is said that only the continuity of consciousness flows and transmigrates, and the continuity of death and birth is already established, what is the use of grasping the continuity of form?
This is unreasonable, because for those who have not yet attained freedom from craving for form, the continuity of consciousness alone, apart from form, cannot flow and transmigrate.

If the continuity of consciousness can flow apart from form, then it would definitely not take form in rebirth. Therefore the continuity of consciousness must be together with form in order to be able to flow and transmigrate to the place of rebirth.
Moreover, a sutra says:
Only bound does one take birth, only bound does one die.
Only by being bound does one go from this world to the next world.
The scriptures say that all those who have not yet abandoned craving for form are bound by the bond of form. Therefore there is no continuity of consciousness alone.

It is also impossible to imagine that the original form of the past continues in a series and goes to the place of rebirth in the next life, because it is clearly seen that the body perishes at the place of death.
Therefore you should understand that there is another form that goes to the next life. Therefore it is reasonable to conclude that the intermediate existence definitely exists.

If you say that you see mind evolving apart from form, that is, that one who dwells here quickly grasps the lunar sphere, or that one who dwells in the capital of Benares thinks of the village of Pataliputra,
the World Honored One also said:
I do not see any dharma that turns and changes as quickly as the mind.
Also, a sutra says:
The mind travels far, goes alone, has no body, and sleeps in a cave.

In this way, apart from the two ends of death and birth, there is no separate intermediate existence that can be obtained. In this way, although there is no intermediate existence between this world and the next world, one goes from this world to the next world.
This is unreasonable, because it has already been explained. The object is not reached, and the support is equally swift.
It has already been explained that it is unreasonable for the mind alone to flow and turn without attachment to form.

Also, eye consciousness and mental consciousness take objects that are not reached. The mind abides here and far away takes the moon disc and remembers a distant village. There is no error. The mind does not go to the object that is remembered.
Never have I seen consciousness arise apart from its support, or never have I seen it without support without error.
By this, I have already explained the mind's distant travel, etc.

Also, the mind quickly turns in its support, object, and aspect. It does not turn quickly by merely going to the object apart from its support. Therefore, we know that the mind, apart from form, does not flow and turn in a continuous series going to the place of rebirth. Therefore, there is a real intermediate state.
Thus, it has been clarified that the image arises connected to substance. The example of death and rebirth in different places is not established.
Therefore, the analogy of an echo is also rejected, because the sound and the valley, etc., are transmitted through a series of intermediaries.

That is, the great elements that are the support of the original sound transmit and produce subtle great elements that spread to the valley, etc., and strike there to produce an echo that resembles the original sound.
Even though there is a series of sounds and echoes in the middle, they are either scattered or faint and therefore inaudible.
If one touches a mountain or valley, etc., in the middle,
then the sound is immediately gathered and accumulated and can be heard.
How do we know this?
Because it is heard at different times.
That is, the listener first hears the original sound and only later hears the echo produced by the sound.

If it is claimed that the hearer hears it without interval in a single moment, then the two moments would be difficult to distinguish, and one would produce the false notion that it is heard in a single moment.
But this is not the case, and we know that the series of sounds is interrupted in the middle, and we are aware that it is heard at different times.
Because of the continuity of sound, it is transmitted to the valley and other places, and then the echo is produced. This further proves that there definitely is an intermediate state.
Doesn't your school also definitely not accept that the continuity of sounds enters the ear to be heard?
How can you say that the continuity of sounds is transmitted, encountering conditions to produce echoes, and is heard at a different time?
Your criticism is not correct, because I do not deny it.
That is to say, the continuity of sounds is not what I deny;
Only the entry of the continuity into the ear to be heard is not accepted by me.

In places where the great elements produce the conditions for sound, there is sound produced through mutual striking, which can be grasped when the conditions for hearing are present.ğŸ”½First, one grasps the sound in the place of the original substance, and later one hears the echo produced in a different place. There is no fault of reaching the sense organ to hear, as in other schools.

The continuity of sounds does not enter the ear to be heard, because there is first the hearing of the sound in the place of the original substance, and later, in a different place, one hears the echo produced apart from the ear sense organ.

If only the sound produced by the ear being pressed could be heard, one should not be able to hear distant sounds or echoes. Therefore it is not that the sound continues to enter the ear and is heard.

It is also not that all sounds do not continue to exist. This is because distant sounds and echoes are heard in different places, and sounds are heard at different times and places. For this reason, the existence of the intermediate state is definitely established.
Other masters say:
Because there are differences in the conditions such as wind, sound continues to reach and is heard, whether or not it is separated from its substance.
